abstract:
  - Bycatch rates are essential to estimating fishery impacts and making management decisions, but data on bycatch are often limited. Tropical tuna purse seine (PS) fisheries catch numerous bycatch species, including vulnerable silky sharks. Even if bycatch proportion is relatively low, impacts on pelagic ecosystems may be important due to the large size of these fisheries. Partial observer coverage of bycatch is a major impediment to assessing impacts. Here we develop a generic $\Delta$ modeling approach for predicting catch of four major bycatch species, including silky sharks, in floating object-associated fishing sets of the French Indian Ocean PS fleet from 2011 to 2018 based on logbook and observer data. Cross-validation and variable selection are used to identify optimal models consisting of a random forest model for presence-absence and a  negative binomial general-additive model for abundance when present. Though models explain small to moderate amounts of variance (5%-15%), they outperform a simpler approach commonly used for reporting and they allow us to estimate total annual bycatch for the four species with robust estimates of uncertainty. Interestingly, uncertainty relative to mean catch is lower for top predators than forage species, consistent with these species having similar behavior and ecological niches to tunas.

# Out-of-bag error estimate for RF model in percent
OOB_estimate <- function (rf){
  cm = rf$confusion[,-ncol(rf$confusion)]
  return((1 - sum(diag(cm)) / sum(cm))*100)
}

# Lower triangle ggplot of correlation matrix
matrice_corr<-function(mat){
  require(tidyverse) # tibble and dplyr # Don't use plyr, reshape2. Also Hmisc is not really necessary
  require(ggplot2)
  
  # Get correlation matrix
  coef.corr = cor(as.matrix(mat),method="pearson")
  coef.corr[!lower.tri(coef.corr)] = NA
  
  mat.m <- coef.corr |> as.data.frame() |> rownames_to_column(var="Var2") |>
    pivot_longer(-Var2,names_to="Var1",values_to="R") |>
    mutate(R = round(R,2),
           Var1 = factor(Var1,levels=colnames(coef.corr)),
           Var2 = factor(Var2,levels=colnames(coef.corr)))
  
  plot_cor=ggplot(mat.m, aes(x=Var1, y=Var2, label=format(R,nsmall=2), fill=abs(R)))+ 
    geom_tile(colour="white")+
    scale_fill_gradient(na.value="white")+
    geom_text(fontface=2,col="white",size=3)+ylab(NULL)+xlab(NULL)+
    theme_bw() +
    theme(text=element_text(size=10),
          axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 40, vjust = 1, hjust=1)) +
    coord_flip()

  return(plot_cor)
}

# Percent of well classified observations
well_class <- function(predict, observation,seuil=0.5) {
  x = (predict>seuil) == observation
  return(sum(x) / length(x))
}

# Root mean square error and mean absolute error
RMSE=function(predict, observation)
  sqrt(mean((predict-observation)^2))

MAE=function(predict, observation)
  mean(abs(predict-observation))

# RMSE divided by the mean prediction
RMSE.coeff=function(predict, observation)
  sqrt(mean((predict-observation)^2))/mean(predict)

# MAE divided by the mean prediction
MAE.coeff=function(predict, observation)
  mean(abs(predict-observation))/mean(predict)

# Work-alike of function from caret to avoid library dependence just for that
createFolds = function(y,k,seed=NULL) {
  if (!is.null(seed))
    set.seed(seed)
  
  x = y |> seq_along() |> sample()
  n = floor(length(y)/k)
  
  x = x[1:(k*n)] |> matrix(ncol=k) |>
    apply(2,sort) |> as.data.frame()
  
  nd = nchar(k)
  names(x) = paste0("Fold",formatC(1:k,format="d",flag="0",width=nd))
  
  return(x)
}

# Deviance explained in percent
deviance_explained<- function(predict,observation){
  f = function(pred,obs)
    sum((pred-obs)^2)

  deviance_model = f(pred=predict,obs=observation)
  deviance_data = f(pred=mean(observation),obs=observation)
  
  return((deviance_data-deviance_model)/deviance_data*100)
}

# Generic function to predict for all models in paper
predict_model = function(model,newdata) {
  # If delta model, call for parts and multiply
  if (class(model)[1] == "delta")
    return(predict_model(model$pres.abs,newdata)*predict_model(model$abund,newdata))
  
  # If random forest, then prediction is simple one step
  if (inherits(model,"randomForest"))
    return(predict(model,newdata=newdata,type="prob")[,2])
  
  # Just return simple prediction after factorizing if lm model (i.e., ratio model)
  if (all(class(model)=="lm")) {
    ft = attr(model$terms,"dataClasses")
    ft = ft[ft=="factor"]
    for (nn in names(ft))
      newdata[[nn]] = as.factor(newdata[[nn]])
    return(predict(model, newdata = newdata, type = "response"))
  }
  
  # If ratio model, use special procedure
  if(inherits(model,"ratio")) {
    newdata = newdata |> dplyr::ungroup() |> dplyr::mutate(row_id=dplyr::row_number()) |>
      dplyr::select(dplyr::all_of(c("row_id",model$strata_cols,model$catch_col))) |>
      merge(model$sums |> dplyr::select(dplyr::all_of(c(model$strata_cols,"ratio"))),
            by=model$strata_cols,all.x=TRUE) |>
      arrange(row_id) # Assures order of data hasn't changed
    
    return(newdata[[model$catch_col]]*newdata$ratio)
  }
  
  # For all others need predictions type="response"
  p = predict(model, newdata = newdata, type = "response")
  
  # If not random forest, proceed to define transformation functions
  invlink_transfo=switch(sub("[(].*[)]$","",model$family$family), # Remove weird stuff from tweedie family name
                         "binomial"=,"Gamma"=identity,
                         "Tweedie"=,"tw"=,"Negative Binomial"=,
                         "nb"=,"Poisson"=,"poisson"=function(x)x+1,
                         "gaussian"=exp,
                         )
  
  if (model$family$family == "gaussian") # Correction for log-normal model
    p = p + summary(model)$scale/2
  
  return(invlink_transfo(p))
}

# Function to run simple "ratio" model + folds
# This version uses a linear regression to calculate things
ratio_lm_model_save= function(strata_cols,dff,espece,seed=NULL,folds=10,
                           sep="*" # Set to ":" to use only interaction terms for strata_cols
                           ){
  dff$y=dff[[espece]] # y is the response variable 

  for(n in strata_cols) # Strata cols should be factors
    dff[[n]] = as.factor(dff[[n]])
  
  form = paste0("y~0+catch:(",paste0(strata_cols,collapse=sep),")") |> formula()

  # RF model 
  model = lm(form,data=dff)
  
  # Prediction 
  pred=predict_model(model,dff)
  
  # Do folds if desired
  pred_folds=NULL
  obs_folds=NULL
  if (!is.null(folds) && (length(folds)>1 || folds>1)) {
    if (!is.null(seed))
      set.seed(seed)
    
    if (is.numeric(folds) && length(folds)==1)
      folds <- createFolds(dff$y, k=folds)
    
    # Prediction of the 10 folds
    pred_folds <- lapply(folds, function (x){
      test <- dff[x,] # 1/10 of data = test data
      train<- dff[-x,] # 9/10 of data = train data
      
      # model on train data
      m <- lm(form, data=train)
      
      # prediction on test data
      return(predict_model(m, newdata = test))
    })
    
    # Observation of the 10 folds 
    obs_folds <-lapply(folds, function (x) dff$y[x])
  }
  
  return(list(model=model,data=dff,preds=strata_cols,
              OBS=dff$y,PRED=pred,
              PRED_folds=pred_folds,
              OBS_folds=obs_folds,folds=folds))
}

# Function to run simple "ratio" model + folds
# This version uses the ratio per strata of total bycatch to total catch
create_ratio_model = function(strata_cols,dff,espece,catch_col="catch") {
  ss = dff |> dplyr::group_by(dplyr::across(dplyr::all_of(strata_cols))) |>
    dplyr::summarize(dplyr::across(dplyr::all_of(c(catch_col,espece)),sum))
  ss$ratio = ss[[espece]] / ss[[catch_col]]
  
  model = list(strata_cols=strata_cols,catch_col=catch_col,species=espece,sums=ss)
  class(model) = "ratio"
  
  return(model)
}

ratio_model_save= function(strata_cols,dff,espece,seed=NULL,folds=10,catch_col="catch"){
  model = create_ratio_model(strata_cols,dff,espece,catch_col=catch_col)
  
  # Prediction 
  pred=predict_model(model,dff)
  
  # Do folds if desired
  pred_folds=NULL
  obs_folds=NULL
  if (!is.null(folds) && (length(folds)>1 || folds>1)) {
    if (!is.null(seed))
      set.seed(seed)
    
    if (is.numeric(folds) && length(folds)==1)
      folds <- createFolds(dff[[espece]], k=folds)
    
    # Prediction of the 10 folds
    pred_folds <- lapply(folds, function (x){
      test <- dff[x,] # 1/10 of data = test data
      train<- dff[-x,] # 9/10 of data = train data
      
      m = create_ratio_model(strata_cols,train,espece,catch_col=catch_col)
      
      # prediction on test data
      return(predict_model(m, newdata = test))
    })
    
    # Observation of the 10 folds 
    obs_folds <-lapply(folds, function (x) dff[[espece]][x])
  }
  
  return(list(model=model,data=dff,preds=strata_cols,
              OBS=dff[[espece]],PRED=pred,
              PRED_folds=pred_folds,
              OBS_folds=obs_folds,folds=folds))
}

# Function to run random forest presence-absence models + folds
rf_save= function(preds,dff,espece,mtry,ntree,seed=NULL,folds=10){
  require(randomForest)
  dff$y=dff[[espece]] > 0 # y is the response variable 
  dff$vessel=as.factor(dff$vessel) # id of the vessel in factor 

  # RF model 
  form <- formula(paste("as.factor(y)",paste0(preds,collapse=" + "), sep="~"))
  model=randomForest(form,data=dff,ntree=ntree,mtry=mtry)
  
  # Prediction 
  pred=predict_model(model,dff)
  
  pred_folds=NULL
  obs_folds=NULL
  if (!is.null(folds) && (length(folds)>1 || folds>1)) {
    # 10 folds
    if (!is.null(seed))
      set.seed(seed)
    
    if (is.numeric(folds) && length(folds)==1)
      folds <- createFolds(dff$y, k=folds)
    
    # Prediction of the 10 folds
    pred_folds<- lapply(folds, function (x){
      test <- dff[x,] # 1/10 of data = test data
      train<- dff[-x,] # 9/10 of data = train data
      
      # model on train data
      mm <- randomForest(form, data=train, ntree=ntree, mtry=mtry)
      
      # prediction on test data
      return(predict_model(mm, newdata = test))
    })
    
    # Observation of the 10 folds 
    obs_folds <-lapply(folds, function (x) dff$y[x])
  }
  
  return(list(model=model,data=dff,preds=preds,
              OBS=dff$y,PRED=pred,
              PRED_folds=pred_folds,
              OBS_folds=obs_folds,folds=folds))
}

# Function to run pres-abs or abundance GAM + folds
gam_save<-function(preds,famille.gam,dff,espece,
                   seed=NULL,folds=10,
                   df = switch(famille.gam,
                               "binomial"=dff,
                               dff[dff[[espece]]>0,]), # Reduce dff to just non-zeros for abundance models
                   link_transfo=switch(famille.gam,
                                       "binomial" = function(x) x>0,
                                       "Gamma"=identity,
                                       "Tweedie"=,"tw"=,"nb"=,"poisson"=function(x)x-1,
                                       "gaussian"=log)){
  require(mgcv)
  df$vessel=as.factor(df$vessel) # id of the vessel in factor 
  
  df$y=link_transfo(df[[espece]]) # Transformed response variable

  if (famille.gam == "binomial") {
    obs = df$y # For binomial, observation is post transformation
  } else {
    obs = df[[espece]] # Otherwise observation is the original untransformed response variable
  }
    
  # Model formula
  form <- formula(paste("y",paste0(preds,collapse=" + "), sep="~"))
  
  # Full GAM model
  model <- gam(form,data=df,family=famille.gam, method = "ML")
  
  # Prediction train 
  pred=predict_model(model, df)
  
  # Do folds if desired
  pred_folds=NULL
  obs_folds=NULL
  if (!is.null(folds) && (length(folds)>1 || folds>1)) {
    if (!is.null(seed))
      set.seed(seed)
    
    if (is.numeric(folds) && length(folds)==1)
      folds <- createFolds(dff$y, k=folds)
    
    # Prediction of the 10 folds
    pred_folds<- lapply(folds, function (x){
      test <- df[x,]
      train<- df[-x,]
      
      mm <- gam(form, data=train, family = famille.gam, method = "ML")
      
      return(predict_model(mm, newdata = test))
    })
    
    # Observation of the 10 folds 
    obs_folds <-lapply(folds,function (x) obs[x] )
  }
  
  return(list(model=model,data=dff,family=famille.gam,
              preds=preds,OBS=obs,PRED=pred,
              OBS_folds=obs_folds,PRED_folds=pred_folds,folds=folds))
}

# Function to run delta model + folds
delta_save<-function(preds.pres.abs,preds.abund,dff,espece,famille.pres.abs,famille.abund,
                     mtry,ntree, seed=NULL,folds=10,
                     link_transfo=switch(famille.abund,
                                         "Gamma"=function(x)x,
                                         "Tweedie"=,"tw"=,"nb"=,"poisson"=function(x)x-1,
                                         "gaussian"=function(x)log(x))){
  
  dff$vessel=as.factor(dff$vessel) # id of the vessel in factor 
  dff$y.orig = dff[[espece]]
  dff$y.pres.abs = dff$y.orig>0 # Pres-abs response variable
  dff$y.abund = link_transfo(dff$y.orig) # Transformed response variable
    
  # Model formula
  pres.abs.y = switch(famille.pres.abs,
                      randomForest.formula=,randomForest=,
                      rf = "as.factor(y.pres.abs)",
                      binomial=,
                      gam = "y.pres.abs")
                      
  form.pres.abs <- formula(paste(pres.abs.y,paste0(preds.pres.abs,collapse=" + "), sep="~"))
  form.abund <- formula(paste("y.abund",paste0(preds.abund,collapse=" + "), sep="~"))
  
  # Pres-abs model
  model.pres.abs = 
    switch(famille.pres.abs,
           randomForest.formula=,randomForest=,
           rf = randomForest::randomForest(form.pres.abs,data=dff,ntree=ntree,mtry=mtry),
           binomial=,
           gam = mgcv::gam(form.pres.abs,data=dff,family="binomial", method = "ML")
    )

  # Abundance model
  model.abund <- mgcv::gam(form.abund,data=dff,subset=dff$y.orig>0,
                           family=famille.abund, method = "ML")

  model = list(pres.abs=model.pres.abs,abund=model.abund)
  class(model) = "delta"
  
  # Base predictions
  pred_pres.abs = predict_model(model.pres.abs, dff)
  pred_abund = predict_model(model.abund, dff)
  pred_delta = pred_pres.abs * pred_abund
  
  # Do folds if desired
  obs_folds=NULL
  obs_pres.abs_folds=NULL
  pred_folds=NULL
  pred_pres.abs_folds=NULL
  pred_abund_folds=NULL
  if (!is.null(folds) && (length(folds)>1 || folds>1)) {
    if (!is.null(seed))
      set.seed(seed)
    
    if (is.numeric(folds) && length(folds)==1)
      folds <- createFolds(dff$y, k=folds)
    
    # Prediction of the 10 folds
    pred_pres.abs_folds<- lapply(folds, function (x){
      test <- dff[x,]
      train<- dff[-x,]
      
      model = 
        switch(famille.pres.abs,
               randomForest.formula=,randomForest=,
               rf = randomForest::randomForest(form.pres.abs,data=train,ntree=ntree,mtry=mtry),
               binomial=,
               gam = mgcv::gam(form.pres.abs,data=train,family="binomial", method = "ML")
        )
      
      return(predict_model(model, newdata = test))
    })
    pred_abund_folds<- lapply(folds, function (x){
      test <- dff[x,]
      train<- dff[-x,]
      train2 <- train[train$y.orig>0,]
      
      model = mgcv::gam(form.abund,data=train2,
                        family=famille.abund, method = "ML")
      
      return(predict_model(model, newdata = test))
    })
    pred_folds = lapply(1:length(pred_abund_folds),
                        function(i) pred_pres.abs_folds[[i]] * pred_abund_folds[[i]])
    
    # Observation of the 10 folds 
    obs_folds <-lapply(folds,function (x) dff$y.orig[x] )
    obs_pres.abs_folds <-lapply(folds,function (x) dff$y.pres.abs[x] )
  }
  
  return(list(model=model,preds.pres.abs=preds.pres.abs,preds.abund=preds.abund,data=dff,
              family.pres.abs = famille.pres.abs, family.abund = famille.abund,
              
              OBS=dff$y.orig, OBS_pres.abs = dff$y.pres.abs,
              PRED=pred_delta,PRED_pres.abs=pred_pres.abs,PRED_abund=pred_abund,
              
              OBS_folds=obs_folds,OBS_pres.abs_folds=obs_pres.abs_folds,
              PRED_folds=pred_folds,PRED_pres.abs_folds=pred_pres.abs_folds,
              PRED_abund_folds=pred_abund_folds,
              folds=folds))
}

# Function to run delta model + folds using existing pres-abs model and overall abundance model
# This function still takes time to run abundance model on folds...
# Necessary to supply species as this isn't saved in single component models
delta_save_quick<-
  function(mod.pres.abs,mod.abund,espece,
           famill.pres.abs = ifelse(inherits(mod.pres.abs$model,"randomForest"),"rf","binomial"),
           famille.abund = sub("[(].*[)]$","",mod.abund$model$family$family),
           link_transfo=switch(famille.abund,
                               "Gamma"=function(x)x,
                               "Tweedie"=,"tw"=,"nb"=,"poisson"=function(x)x-1,
                               "gaussian"=function(x)log(x))){
  dff = mod.pres.abs$data
  dff$vessel=as.factor(dff$vessel) # id of the vessel in factor 
  dff$y.orig = dff[[espece]]
  dff$y.pres.abs = dff$y.orig>0 # Pres-abs response variable
  dff$y.abund = link_transfo(dff$y.orig) # Transformed response variable
  dff$y = dff$y.abund # I called the response variable y in gam_save, so I need this to rerun abundance models...
    
  # Model formula
  form.abund <- mod.abund$model$formula
  
  # Pres-abs model
  model.pres.abs = mod.pres.abs$model

  # Abundance model
  model.abund = mod.abund$model

  model = list(pres.abs=model.pres.abs,abund=model.abund)
  class(model) = "delta"
  
  # Base predictions
  pred_pres.abs = mod.pres.abs$PRED
  pred_abund = predict_model(model.abund, dff)
  pred_delta = pred_pres.abs * pred_abund
  
  # Do folds if desired
  obs_folds=NULL
  obs_pres.abs_folds=NULL
  pred_folds=NULL
  pred_pres.abs_folds=NULL
  pred_abund_folds=NULL
  folds = mod.pres.abs$folds
  if (!is.null(folds) && (length(folds)>1 || folds>1)) {
    # Prediction of the 10 folds
    pred_pres.abs_folds = mod.pres.abs$PRED_folds
    
    pred_abund_folds<- lapply(folds, function (x){
      test <- dff[x,]
      train<- dff[-x,]
      train2 <- train[train$y.orig>0,]
      
      model = mgcv::gam(form.abund,data=train2,
                        family=famille.abund, method = "ML")
      
      return(predict_model(model, newdata = test))
    })
    pred_folds = lapply(1:length(pred_abund_folds),
                        function(i) pred_pres.abs_folds[[i]] * pred_abund_folds[[i]])
    
    # Observation of the 10 folds 
    obs_folds <-lapply(folds,function (x) dff$y.orig[x] )
    obs_pres.abs_folds <-lapply(folds,function (x) dff$y.pres.abs[x] )
  }
  
  return(list(model=model,preds.pres.abs=mod.pres.abs$preds,preds.abund=mod.abund$preds,data=dff,
              family.pres.abs = famille.pres.abs, family.abund = famille.abund,
              
              OBS=dff$y.orig, OBS_pres.abs = dff$y.pres.abs,
              PRED=pred_delta,PRED_pres.abs=pred_pres.abs,PRED_abund=pred_abund,
              
              OBS_folds=obs_folds,OBS_pres.abs_folds=obs_pres.abs_folds,
              PRED_folds=pred_folds,PRED_pres.abs_folds=pred_pres.abs_folds,
              PRED_abund_folds=pred_abund_folds,
              folds=folds))
}

# Helper function to get all the results at once
model_stats = function(predict,observation)
  c(RMSE=RMSE(predict,observation),
    MAE=MAE(predict,observation),
    RMSE.coeff=RMSE.coeff(predict,observation),
    MAE.coeff=MAE.coeff(predict,observation),
    dev.expl.perc=deviance_explained(predict = predict,observation = observation)
    )

# Function that gets major stats for models, including folds
model_results = function(model_espece){
  # Figure out if it a pres-abs or abund model
  pres.abs = inherits(model_espece$model,"randomForest") ||
    (inherits(model_espece$model,"gam") && model_espece$model$family$family=="binomial")

  ## full model stats
  ms = model_stats(predict=model_espece$PRED, observation = model_espece$OBS)
  
  if (pres.abs) # if pres-abs, add well_classified
    ms = c(ms,well_classified=well_class(predict=model_espece$PRED,
                                         observation=model_espece$OBS))
  
  # Find number of folds
  nfolds = length(model_espece$PRED_folds)
  
  # Get stats for all folds
  res=c()
  if (nfolds>0) {
    res = sapply(1:nfolds,function(i) {
      obs = model_espece$OBS_folds[[i]]
      pred = model_espece$PRED_folds[[i]]
      ms = model_stats(predict = pred, observation = obs)
      
      if (pres.abs)
        ms = c(ms,well_classified=well_class(predict=pred,observation=obs))
      
      return(ms)
    }) |> apply(1,mean) # Get means over folds
    
    # Add v. prefix
    names(res) = paste0("v.",names(res))
  }
  
  # Extra statistics for specific model types
  extra = switch(class(model_espece$model)[1],
                 lm=c(AIC=AIC(model_espece$model),
                      mod.r.squared.perc=summary(model_espece$model)$r.squared*100),
                 gam=c(AIC=model_espece$model$aic,
                       mod.dev.expl.perc=summary(model_espece$model)$dev.expl*100),
                 rf=,randomForest.formula=,
                 randomForest=c(OOB.perc=OOB_estimate(model_espece$model)),
                 c()
                 )
  
  return(c(ms,res,extra))
}

```{r gam_selections_functions}
# Does variable selection for GAMs based on p-values
# This will not work well with te() or ti() smooths - manually check that these are significant
select_optimal_gam = 
  function(dff,famille.gam,espece,
           full_gam_terms = get("full_gam_terms",parent.frame()),
           flat_gam_terms = get("flat_gam_terms",parent.frame()),
           short_gam_terms = setNames(names(full_gam_terms),sub(",by=[^,)]+","",names(full_gam_terms)))) {
    # If fail, save image so that we can figure out why
    on.exit(if (!finished) save(list = ls(all.names = TRUE), file = "ERROR.select_optimal_gam.RData",envir = environment()))
    finished=FALSE
    
    full_gam = paste0(full_gam_terms,collapse=" + ")
    
    gam_full = gam_save(pred=full_gam,famille.gam=famille.gam,dff=dff,espece=espece,folds=0)
    
    terms = full_gam_terms
    model = gam_full$model
    gam_optimal = gam_full
    res = list(list(kept_terms=terms,dropped_term=character(),added_term=character(),model=model))
    aa = anova(model)

    # Fix for terms with a `by` clause
    tt = aa$s.table[,"p-value",drop=FALSE] |> 
      as.data.frame() |> rownames_to_column("byterm") |>
      mutate(grp = sub(":.*$","",byterm)) |> group_by(grp) |>
      summarize(`p-value`=min(`p-value`)) |>
      mutate(term=ifelse(grp %in% names(short_gam_terms),
                         short_gam_terms[grp],grp) # Get term name names back for things using `by` clause
      ) |>
      bind_rows(aa$pTerms.table[,"p-value",drop=FALSE] |> as.data.frame() |>
                  rownames_to_column("term"))
    
    while (length(terms)>0 && any(tt[["p-value"]]>0.05)) {
      i = which.max(tt[["p-value"]])
      tn = tt$term[i]
      dropped_term = terms[tn]
      
      if (grepl("^(s|ti|te) *[(]",dropped_term)) {
        added_term = flat_gam_terms[[tn]]
        I = which(terms==dropped_term)
        t1 = terms[1:I][-I]
        t2 = terms[-1:-I]
        terms = c(t1,setNames(added_term,added_term),t2)
      } else {
        added_term = c()
        terms = terms[terms!=dropped_term]
      }

      pred = paste0(terms,collapse=" + ")
      gam_optimal = gam_save(pred=pred,famille.gam=famille.gam,
                             dff=dff,espece=espece,folds=0)
      model = gam_optimal$model
      
      aa = anova(model)
      tt = rbind(aa$pTerms.table[,"p-value",drop=FALSE],
                 aa$s.table[,"p-value",drop=FALSE])
      
      # Fix for terms with a `by` clause
      tt = aa$s.table[,"p-value",drop=FALSE] |> 
        as.data.frame() |> rownames_to_column("byterm") |>
        mutate(grp = sub(":.*$","",byterm)) |> group_by(grp) |>
        summarize(`p-value`=min(`p-value`)) |>
        mutate(term=ifelse(grp %in% names(short_gam_terms),
                           short_gam_terms[grp],grp) # Get term name names back for things using `by` clause
        ) |>
        bind_rows(aa$pTerms.table[,"p-value",drop=FALSE] |> as.data.frame() |>
                    rownames_to_column("term"))
      
      res[[length(res)+1]] = list(kept_terms=terms,dropped_term=dropped_term,
                                  added_term=added_term,model=model)
    }
    
    finished=TRUE
    return(list(gam_optimal=gam_optimal,gam_full=gam_full,gam_selections=res))
}

```{r prediction_interval_functions}
# Function that will compute a prediction interval for an arbitrary GAM
pi_sims_gam = function(model,newdata,n=1e4,alpha=0.05,
                       probs=c(alpha/2,1-alpha/2),return.sims=FALSE) {
  family = sub("[(].*[)]$","",model$family$family)
  invlink = model$family$linkinv
  
  # Model family must be known to this function so as to be able
  # to identify how to draw values 
  # from the distribution family, simulated means and other parameters contained
  # in the model (e.g., the scale parameter). 

  # Get simulated coefficients
  beta <- coef(model) # coefficients
  V <- vcov(model) # covariance of coefficients
  Cv <- chol(V) # Cholevsky factorisation of covariance
  nus <- rnorm(n * length(beta)) # Unit normally distributed values
  beta_sims <- beta + t(Cv) %*% matrix(nus, nrow = length(beta), ncol = n) # Simulated coefficients

  # Get predictions in linear space
  lpmat <- predict(model, newdata = newdata, type = "lpmatrix")
  linpred_sims <- lpmat %*% beta_sims
  
  # Simulated responses after applying inverse link function
  val_sims <- invlink(linpred_sims)
  
  # Simulated predictions drawn from distribution
  y_sims = switch(family,
                  binomial=rbinom(n = prod(dim(val_sims)), size = 1,
                                  prob = val_sims),
                  gaussian=rnorm(n = prod(dim(val_sims)), mean = val_sims, 
                                 sd = sqrt(summary(model)$scale)),
                  poisson=rpois(n = prod(dim(val_sims)), lambda = val_sims),
                  "Negative Binomial"=,
                  nb=rnbinom(n = prod(dim(val_sims)), mu = val_sims,
                             size=model$family$getTheta(TRUE)),
                  "Tweedie"=,
                  tw=mgcv::rTweedie(mu = val_sims,
                                    p = model$family$getTheta(TRUE),
                                    phi = summary(model)$scale),
                  stop("Uknown model family: ",family)) |> 
    matrix(ncol=ncol(val_sims),nrow=nrow(val_sims))
  
  qq = apply(y_sims,1,quantile,probs=probs) |> t() |> as.data.frame()
  
  if (return.sims) {
    res = list(quantiles=qq,sims=y_sims)
  } else {
    res = qq
  }
  
  return(res)
}

# Function that calculates the prediction interval for delta and ratio models
prediction_interval = function(model,newdata, n=1e4, probs=c(0.025,0.975),
                               return.sims=FALSE) {
  # If lm model, this indicates that it is a ratio model. 
  # Just use internal prediction interval calc of lm models.
  if (all(class(model)=="lm")) {
    ft = attr(model$terms,"dataClasses")
    ft = ft[ft=="factor"]
    for (nn in names(ft))
      newdata[[nn]] = as.factor(newdata[[nn]])
    return(predict(model,newdata,type="response",interval="prediction",level=diff(probs)))
  }

  # Check if model of class delta
  if (!(class(model)[1] == "delta"))
    stop("Model must be of type delta or lm (i.e., ratio model)")
  
  # Simulate presence-absence values depending on model type
  if (inherits(model$pres.abs,"randomForest")) {
    p = predict_model(model$pres.abs,newdata)
    p = matrix(p,nrow=length(p),ncol=n)
    
    p = rbinom(n = prod(dim(p)), size = 1, prob = p)
  } else {
    p = pi_sims_gam(model$pres.abs,newdata,n=n,return.sims=TRUE)$sims
  }
  
  # Simulate abundance values
  lab = pi_sims_gam(model$abund,newdata,n=n,return.sims=TRUE)$sims
  
  # Invert transformation of abundance
  family = sub("[(].*[)]$","",model$abund$family$family)
  lab = switch(family,
               gaussian=exp(lab),
               Gamma=lab,
               "Tweedie"=,"tw"=,"nb"=,"Negative Binomial"=,"poisson"=lab+1,
               stop("Uknown model family: ",family))

  # Combine into delta model simulated predictions
  sims = p * lab
  
  # Get quantiles
  qu = sims |> apply(1,quantile,probs=probs) |> t() |> as.data.frame()
  
  if (return.sims) {
    return(list(sims=sims,quantiles=qu))
  } else {
    return(qu)
  }
}

## Some info about default color palettes
## Default for mgcViz::l_fitRaster: viridis::viridis(50, begin = 0.2)
## Default for mgcv::vis.gam: heat.colors(50)

# Small function to make individual effect plots
my_plot_gam_viz = function(v,n,yl,t,ybar=NULL,s=dstats,fgt=flat_gam_terms,fill_guide=FALSE,
                           colours=heat.colors(50)) {
  require(mgcViz)
  if (grepl("^t[ie][(]",yl)) {
    x = plot(sm(v, n)) + labs(title = t) +
      l_fitRaster() + scale_fill_gradientn(colours=colours) + labs(fill=paste0(substr(yl,1,2),"(x,y)")) +
      l_fitContour() + l_points()
    
    if (grepl("lon *, *lat",yl)) # If lon,lat add world
      x = x + annotation_map(map_data("world"))
    
    if (!fill_guide)
      x = x + guides(fill = "none")  
  } else {
    ll = (s |> filter(Abbreviation == fgt[[yl]][1]))$ll
    ul = (s |> filter(Abbreviation == fgt[[yl]][1]))$ul

    x = plot(sm(v, n)) + l_ciPoly() + l_fitLine() + labs(title = t) + ylab(yl)
    
    # Automagically determine where to put the bar
    if (is.null(ybar)) {
      ff = x$data$fit
      ybar = min(ff$y - 2*ff$se)
    }
    
    if (length(ll)>0 && !is.na(ll))
      x = x + geom_segment(aes(x = ll,y = ybar,xend = ul,yend = ybar),colour = "red")  
  }
  
  return(x)
}

# A specialized function to plot lon,lat effects when implemented using ti() and by=quarter
my_plot_gam_geo_quarter = 
  function(model,quarter,lon.lat=c("lon","lat"),contour.col="black",too.far=0.1,asp=1,
           world.col="lightgray",world.border="darkgray",
           cond=list(quarter=quarter, month = 2 + 3 * (as.numeric(as.character(quarter))-1) ),
           ...) {
    require(sf)
    require(tmap)
    suppressWarnings(data("World",package="tmap",overwrite=FALSE))
    
    mgcv::vis.gam(model,view=lon.lat,cond=cond,plot.type="contour",
                  contour.col=contour.col,too.far=too.far,asp=asp,...)
    plot(World[1],add=TRUE,col=world.col,border=world.border) 
  }

lat_all = ncvar_get(all,"latitude")
depth_all=ncvar_get(all,"depth")

nc_close(all)

# time limit
t_all_ts = as.POSIXct("1950-01-01",tz="UTC") + as.difftime(t_all,units="hours") # Times of env data
xx = as.POSIXct(range(ecd_ind_fob$d_act))+as.difftime(12,units="hours") # Day range of ECD data
cc = which(diff(t_all_ts >= xx[1] & t_all_ts <= xx[2])!=0) + c(0,1) # element ID's of limits
liminf_time=cc[1]
limsup_time=cc[2]

# lat limite 
lt = range(ecd_ind_fob$lat)
liminf_lat=max(which(lat_all<lt[1]))
limsup_lat=min(which(lat_all>lt[2]))

# long limit 
ln = range(ecd_ind_fob$lon)
liminf_lon=max(which(lon_all<ln[1]))
limsup_lon=min(which(lon_all>ln[2]))

# depth limit
limdepth=max(which(depth_all<=200))

# Productivity data ----

# URL for data
dimension=paste0('longitude[',liminf_lon,':',1,':',limsup_lon,
                 '],latitude[',liminf_lat,':',1,':',limsup_lat,
                 '],depth[',0,':',1,':',limdepth,
                 '],time[',liminf_time,':',1,':',limsup_time,
                 '],nppv[',liminf_time,':',1,':',limsup_time,'][',0,':',1,':',limdepth,'][',liminf_lat,':',1,':',limsup_lat,
                 '][',liminf_lon,':',1,':',limsup_lon,']')
url = paste0(copernicus_url_base,data_path,"?",dimension)

# # stars approach - requires up to date packages -----
# # This seems simpler, but is way slower
# nppv = stars::read_ncdf(url,"nppv")
# pro = stars::st_extract(nppv,st_coordinates(ecd_ind_fob_env)[1:2,],time_column="d_act_ts")

# Brute force approach ----
o = nc_open(url)

# Read in spatial and temporal dimensions of this object
ct = ncvar_get(o,"time") # hours since 1950-01-01 00:00:00
ct_ts = as.POSIXct("1950-01-01",tz="UTC") + as.difftime(ct,units="hours") # Times of env data
clon = ncvar_get(o,"longitude")
clat = ncvar_get(o,"latitude")

# Get space-time indexes of closest grid cells...
xx = ecd_ind_fob_env |> select(lon,lat,d_act_ts) |> 
  mutate(loni = sapply(lon,\(.) which.min(abs(.-clon))), # \() is shorthand for function()
         lati = sapply(lat,\(.) which.min(abs(.-clat))),
         ti = sapply(d_act_ts,\(.) which.min(abs(.-ct_ts)))
         ) |>
  mutate(clon = clon[loni],clat=clat[lati],ct=ct_ts[ti])

pro = sapply(1:nrow(xx),
             \(i) {
               ncvar_get(o,"nppv",
                         start = c(xx$loni[i],xx$lati[i],1,xx$ti[i]),
                         count=c(1,1,limdepth,1)) |> sum(na.rm=TRUE) # na.rm for few spots with <200m depth
             })

nc_close(o)

# Put data in place
ecd_ind_fob_env$PRO = pro
```

        .optimal=gam_abund_sel[[sp]]$opt_terms,
        .opt_no_vessel={ pa = gam_abund_sel[[sp]]$opt_terms; pa[pa!="vessel"] },
        .no_vessel_opt=gam_abund_sel[[sp]]$no_vessel_opt_terms,
        stop("Something is wrong")
        )
      mod = gam_save(preds=preds.abund,famille.gam=chosen_gam_abund_family,
                     dff=data_for_models_obs,espece=sp,folds=folds[[sp]])

```{r perdict_performance_scales,eval=!file.exists(fn.pps)}
t_scales = c(row_id="No agg.",month="Month",bimonth="Bi-month",quarter="Quarter",
             halfyear="Half year",year="Year",ocean_str="All time")
s_scales = c(row_id="No agg.",cwp11="1x1",cwp55="5x5",ocean_str="All ocean")

scales = expand_grid(species=names(crit_species),temporal=names(t_scales)[-1],spatial=names(s_scales)[-1]) |>
  bind_rows(data.frame(species=names(crit_species),temporal="row_id",spatial="row_id")) |>
  mutate(temporal2 = ifelse(temporal=="ocean_str","ocean_str","year")) |>
  mutate(species_name=crit_species[species],temporal_name=t_scales[temporal],spatial_name=s_scales[spatial]) |>
  mutate(species_name=factor(species_name,levels=crit_species),
         temporal_name=factor(temporal_name,levels=t_scales),
         spatial_name=factor(spatial_name,levels=s_scales))

mods = lapply(setNames(names(crit_species),names(crit_species)),
              \(sp) readRDS(paste0("output_data/delta.",sp,".rf.",chosen_gam_abund_family,".optimal.RDS")))

nn = lapply(1:nrow(scales),\(ii){
  sp = scales$species[ii]
  agg = unique(c(scales$temporal2[ii],scales$temporal[ii],scales$spatial[ii]))
  
  # Stats for straight predictions
  rr0 = mods[[sp]]$data |>
    mutate(row_id=row_number()) |>
    select(all_of(agg)) |>
    bind_cols(PRED=mods[[sp]]$PRED,OBS=mods[[sp]]$OBS) |>
    group_by(across(all_of(agg))) |>
    summarize(PRED=sum(PRED),OBS=sum(OBS)) |> 
    group_by() |> summarize(RMSE.coeff=RMSE.coeff(PRED,OBS),
                            MAE.coeff=MAE.coeff(PRED,OBS))
  
  fs = mods[[sp]]$folds
  pfs = mods[[sp]]$PRED_folds |> setNames(names(fs)) |> as.data.frame()
  ofs = mods[[sp]]$OBS_folds |> setNames(names(fs)) |> as.data.frame()
  
  # Stats for folds
  rr = lapply(1:length(fs),\(jj){
    mods[[sp]]$data[fs[[jj]],] |>
      mutate(row_id=row_number()) |>
      select(all_of(agg)) |>
      bind_cols(PRED=pfs[[jj]],OBS=ofs[[jj]]) |>
      group_by(across(all_of(agg))) |>
      summarize(PRED=sum(PRED),OBS=sum(OBS)) |> 
      group_by() |> summarize(v.RMSE.coeff=RMSE.coeff(PRED,OBS),
                              v.MAE.coeff=MAE.coeff(PRED,OBS))
  }) |> (\(.) do.call(bind_rows,.))() |>
    summarize(across(everything(),mean)) 
  
  return(bind_cols(rr0,rr))
}) |> (\(.) do.call(bind_rows,.))()

predict_performance_scales = bind_cols(scales,nn)
saveRDS(predict_performance_scales,fn.pps)

<!-- Prediction intervals -->

```{r predict_int_calcs,eval=!file.exists(fn.pic)}
# This predicts results for sets with no observer data

# Identify parts for vessels with observations and vessels without
data_for_models_noobs = data_for_models_noobs |> 
  mutate(vessel_no_obs = vessel %in% vessel_noobs)
I = data_for_models_noobs$vessel_no_obs

# Coordinates to be used for spatial aggregation
# Create our own lon,lat coords instead of using cwp11 as this will allow more flexibility
spatial_agg_scale = 5
data_for_models_noobs = data_for_models_noobs |>
  mutate(lon_grid = floor(lon/spatial_agg_scale) * spatial_agg_scale + spatial_agg_scale/2,
         lat_grid = floor(lat/spatial_agg_scale)*spatial_agg_scale + spatial_agg_scale/2)
data_for_models_obs = data_for_models_obs |>
  mutate(lon_grid = floor(lon/spatial_agg_scale) * spatial_agg_scale + spatial_agg_scale/2,
         lat_grid = floor(lat/spatial_agg_scale) * spatial_agg_scale + spatial_agg_scale/2)

# Predict delta models for each species
fnsv = paste0("output_data/delta.",names(crit_species),".rf.",chosen_gam_abund_family,".optimal.RDS") |>
  setNames(names(crit_species))
fnsnv = paste0("output_data/delta.",names(crit_species),".rf.",chosen_gam_abund_family,".no_vessel_opt.RDS") |>
  setNames(names(crit_species))
delta_annual_results = NULL
delta_grid_results = NULL
delta_obs_annual_results = NULL
for (sp in names(crit_species)) {
  modv = readRDS(fnsv[sp])
  modnv = readRDS(fnsnv[sp])

  vn = paste0(sp,"_delta")
  data_for_models_obs[,vn] = predict_model(modv$model,data_for_models_obs) # Data with observations
  data_for_models_noobs[!I,vn] = predict_model(modv$model,data_for_models_noobs[!I,])
  data_for_models_noobs[I,vn] = predict_model(modnv$model,data_for_models_noobs[I,])
  
  vnl = paste0(sp,"_delta_ll")
  vnu = paste0(sp,"_delta_ul")
  
  # With obs
  xvo = prediction_interval(modv$model,data_for_models_obs,n=nsims,return.sims = TRUE)
  data_for_models_obs[,vnl] = xvo$quantiles[,"2.5%"]
  data_for_models_obs[,vnu] = xvo$quantiles[,"97.5%"]
  
  # Without obs for vessels with obs
  xv = prediction_interval(modv$model,data_for_models_noobs[!I,],n=nsims,return.sims = TRUE)
  data_for_models_noobs[!I,vnl] = xv$quantiles[,"2.5%"]
  data_for_models_noobs[!I,vnu] = xv$quantiles[,"97.5%"]
  
  # Without obs for vessels without obs
  xnv = prediction_interval(modnv$model,data_for_models_noobs[I,],n=nsims,return.sims = TRUE)
  data_for_models_noobs[I,vnl] = xnv$quantiles[,"2.5%"]
  data_for_models_noobs[I,vnu] = xnv$quantiles[,"97.5%"]

  #### Annual predictions with uncertainty ####
  # Compute annual mean predictions
  dd = data_for_models_noobs |> group_by(year) |> 
    summarize(across(all_of(vn),sum),nsets_noobs=n()) |>
    rename_with(~gsub(paste0(sp,"_"),"",.x))
  
  # Aggregate simulations by year, compute quantiles and bind back with annual mean predictions
  av = aggregate(xv$sims,list(year=data_for_models_noobs$year[!I]),sum)
  anv = aggregate(xnv$sims,list(year=data_for_models_noobs$year[I]),sum)
  aa = bind_rows(av,anv) |> group_by(year) |>
    summarize(across(everything(),sum))
  aaa = apply(aa |> select(-year),1,quantile,prob=c(0.025,0.975)) |>
    t() |> bind_cols(year=aa$year) |> mutate(species=sp) |>
    merge(dd,by="year") |> relocate(c(year,nsets_noobs,species,delta),.before=1)
  
  # Add this species to previous species
  delta_annual_results = bind_rows(delta_annual_results,aaa)
  
  #### Aggregate over space also ####
  dd = data_for_models_noobs |> group_by(lon_grid,lat_grid) |> 
    summarize(across(all_of(vn),sum),nsets_noobs=n()) |>
    rename_with(~gsub(paste0(sp,"_"),"",.x))
  
  # Aggregate simulations by year, compute quantiles and bind back with annual mean predictions
  av = aggregate(xv$sims,data_for_models_noobs[!I,c("lon_grid","lat_grid")],sum)
  anv = aggregate(xnv$sims,data_for_models_noobs[I,c("lon_grid","lat_grid")],sum)
  aa = bind_rows(av,anv) |> group_by(lon_grid,lat_grid) |>
    summarize(across(everything(),sum))
  aaa = apply(aa |> select(-lon_grid,-lat_grid),1,quantile,prob=c(0.025,0.975)) |>
    t() |> bind_cols(aa[c("lon_grid","lat_grid")]) |> mutate(species=sp) |>
    merge(dd,by=c("lon_grid","lat_grid")) |> relocate(c(lon_grid,lat_grid,nsets_noobs,species,delta),.before=1)
  
  # Add this species to previous species
  delta_grid_results = bind_rows(delta_grid_results,aaa)
  
  #### Annual uncertainty for data with obs ####
  dd = data_for_models_obs |> group_by(year) |> 
    summarize(across(all_of(c(sp,vn)),sum),nsets_obs=n()) |>
    rename_with(~gsub(sp,"obs",gsub(paste0(sp,"_"),"",.x)))
  
  # Aggregate simulations by year, compute quantiles and bind back with annual mean predictions
  aa = aggregate(xvo$sims,data_for_models_obs["year"],sum) |> group_by(year)
  aaa = apply(aa |> select(-year),1,quantile,prob=c(0.025,0.975)) |>
    t() |> bind_cols(year=aa$year) |> mutate(species=sp) |>
    merge(dd,by="year") |> relocate(c(year,nsets_obs,species,obs,delta),.before=1)
  
  # Add this species to previous species
  delta_obs_annual_results = bind_rows(delta_obs_annual_results,aaa)
  
}

# Predict ratio models for each species
fnsr = paste0("output_data/ratio_model.",names(crit_species),".RDS") |>
  setNames(names(crit_species))
for (sp in names(crit_species)) {
  modr = readRDS(fnsr[sp])

  vn = paste0(sp,"_ratio")
  data_for_models_noobs[[vn]] = predict_model(modr$model,data_for_models_noobs)
}

ratio_annual_results = data_for_models_noobs |> group_by(year) |>
  summarize(across(matches("_ratio$"),sum)) |>
  pivot_longer(cols=all_of(matches("_ratio$")),
               names_pattern="^([^_]+)_ratio$",names_to="species",values_to="ratio")

# Sum up observations by year
obs_annual_results = data_for_models_obs |> group_by(year) |>
  summarize(across(names(crit_species),sum),nsets_obs=n()) |>
  pivot_longer(cols=all_of(names(crit_species)),names_to="species",values_to="obs")

# Sum up observations by spatial strata
obs_grid_results = data_for_models_obs |> group_by(lon_grid,lat_grid) |>
  summarize(across(names(crit_species),sum),nsets_obs=n()) |>
  pivot_longer(cols=all_of(names(crit_species)),names_to="species",values_to="obs")

# Put them all together
annual_results = delta_annual_results |> 
  merge(ratio_annual_results,by=c("year","species")) |>
  merge(obs_annual_results,by=c("year","species")) |>
  mutate(across(delta:ratio,.fns=list(obs=~.x+obs),.names="{.col}_{.fn}"),
         nsets_tot = nsets_obs + nsets_noobs) |>
  relocate(nsets_obs,nsets_noobs,nsets_tot,.after=year)

lonlat_grid_results = delta_grid_results |> 
  merge(obs_grid_results,by=c("lon_grid","lat_grid","species")) |>
  mutate(across(delta:`97.5%`,.fns=list(obs=~.x+obs),.names="{.col}_{.fn}"),
         nsets_tot = nsets_obs + nsets_noobs) |>
  relocate(nsets_obs,nsets_noobs,nsets_tot,.after=lat_grid) |>
  mutate(across(delta:`97.5%`,.fns=list(pset=~(.x+obs)/nsets_tot),.names="{.col}_{.fn}")) |>
  st_as_sf(coords=c("lon_grid","lat_grid"),crs=4326) |>
  rename(centroid_grid=geometry)

lonlat_grid_results$poly_grid = 
  lapply(1:nrow(lonlat_grid_results),
         \(.) st_as_sfc(tmaptools::bb(lonlat_grid_results$centroid_grid[.],
                                      width=spatial_agg_scale,height=spatial_agg_scale,relative=FALSE))) |>
  (\(.)do.call("c",.))()
st_geometry(lonlat_grid_results) = "poly_grid"

save(lonlat_grid_results,delta_grid_results,obs_grid_results,
     annual_results,delta_annual_results,
     ratio_annual_results,obs_annual_results,
     spatial_agg_scale,
     file=fn.pic)

<!-- Spatial & temporal autocorrelation analyses on Delta residuals -->

```{r deltaresidautocorr, include=FALSE, eval=TRUE}
library(sf)
library(gstat)
library(geoR)
library(spacetime)
library(tsibble)

p_nsim <- 99 # CI variogram simulation
nboot <- 99 # bootstrap ACF

fns = paste0("output_data/delta.",names(crit_species),".rf.",chosen_gam_abund_family,".optimal.RDS") |>
  setNames(names(crit_species))

ofns = paste0("output_data/autocorr.delta.",names(crit_species),".rf.",chosen_gam_abund_family,".optimal.RDS") |>
  setNames(names(crit_species))

foreach (sp = names(crit_species)[!file.exists(ofns)],
         .packages=c(.packages,"sf","gstat","geoR","spacetime","tsibble")) %dopar% {
  fn = fns[sp]
  ofn = ofns[sp]
  
  m = readRDS(fn)
  
  data = m$data |>
    mutate(obs = m$OBS, pred = m$PRED, res = pred-obs,
           unik_location = paste(lat, lon, sep = "_"),
           unik_st = paste(lat,lon,d_act,sep="_"))
 
  ## Spatial autocorrelation
  
  # Randomly select one location if there are duplicates
  data_red <- data |> group_by(unik_location) %>%  slice_sample(n = 1)
  
  # Package data for geoR
  geod <-as.geodata(data_red,coords.col=c(which(colnames(data_red) == "lon"),
                                          which(colnames(data_red) == "lat")),
                    data.col=which(colnames(data) %in% c("obs","res")))
  
  # observed data
  vario_obs <- variog(coords = geod[[1]], data = geod[[2]][,"obs"],pairs.min = 30,
                      max.dist = 30, uvec = seq(0, 30, length = 30))
  env_obs <- variog.mc.env(coords = geod[[1]], data = geod[[2]][,"obs"], 
                           obj.var = vario_obs, nsim = p_nsim)
  
  # residuals
  vario_res <- variog(coords = geod[[1]], data = geod[[2]][,"res"],pairs.min = 30,
                      max.dist = 30, uvec = seq(0, 30, length = 30))
  env_res <- variog.mc.env(coords = geod[[1]], data = geod[[2]][,"res"], 
                           obj.var = vario_res, nsim = p_nsim)
  
  spatial_res = list(vario_obs=vario_obs,env_obs=env_obs,
                     vario_res=vario_res,env_res=env_res,
                     data=data_red)
  
  ## Temporal autocorrelation
  list_acf_obs <- vector("list", length = nboot)
  list_acf_res <- vector("list", length = nboot)
  
  lag.max=60
  for(i in 1:nboot) {
    data_red_tmp <- data |> group_by(d_act) |>  slice_sample(n = 1) |>
      arrange(d_act)
    
    nt = nrow(data_red_tmp)
    
    data_red_tmp_tsbl_reg <- as_tsibble(data_red_tmp, index = "d_act") |>
      fill_gaps(obs = NA, res = NA) |>   tsibble::group_by_key() 
    list_acf_obs[[i]] <- as.data.frame(t(as.data.frame(acf(data_red_tmp_tsbl_reg$obs,
                                                           na.action = na.pass,
                                                           lag.max = lag.max, plot = F)$acf)))
    list_acf_res[[i]] <- as.data.frame(t(as.data.frame(acf(data_red_tmp_tsbl_reg$res,
                                                           na.action = na.pass,
                                                           lag.max = lag.max, plot = F)$acf)))
  }
  acf_obs <- dplyr::bind_rows(list_acf_obs)
  acf_res <- dplyr::bind_rows(list_acf_res)
  
  temporal_res = list(acf_res=acf_res,acf_obs=acf_obs,lag = 0:lag.max,
                      lag.max=lag.max, na.action=na.pass,n_timestamps = nt)
  
  ## Spatio-temporal
  data_red_st = data |> group_by(unik_st) %>%  slice_sample(n = 1)
  data_red_st = data_red
  x = st_as_sf(data_red_st,coords=c("lon","lat"),crs=4326)
  y = as_Spatial(st_geometry(x)) # Currently need to use legacy sp functionality for gstat
  t = as.POSIXct(data_red_st$d_act,tz="GMT")
  
  timeDF <- spacetime::STIDF(sp=y,time=t,data=droplevels(as.data.frame(data_red_st)))
  
  p_tunit <- "days"
  p_t_lags <- seq(1,16,1)
  p_cutoff <- 500

  stvariogram_res <- gstat::variogramST(res ~ 1, data = timeDF,
                                      tunit = p_tunit, tlags= p_t_lags,
                                      cutoff = p_cutoff  , width = 50, 
                                      assumeRegular=FALSE, na.omit=TRUE)

  st_res = list(data=data_red_st,variogram=stvariogram_res,
                tunit=p_tunit,tlags=p_t_lags,cutoff=p_cutoff)
  
  ## Save result
  res = list(spatial=spatial_res,temporal=temporal_res,spatiotemporal=st_res)
  saveRDS(res,file=ofn)
}

<!------------ Main text -------------------->

# Introduction

Purse seine fishing is a fishing technique that consists of targeting
and catching entire fish schools in surface waters by encircling them with
a fishing net called a seine. In the tropical oceans, purse seine (PS)
is used extensively to target tropical tunas, specifically skipjack
tuna (*Katsuwonus pelamis*), yellowfin tuna (*Thunnus albacares*) and bigeye
tuna (*Thunnus obesus*) [@kaplanSpatialManagementIndian2014a]. Tropical
tuna fisheries are extremely important economically and in terms of
protein provision for human consumption
[@amandeBycatchEuropeanPurse2010a; @bellRealisingFoodSecurity2019],
catching annually over 2 million tons of target tunas worldwide [@ponsBenefitsConcernsSolutionsaccepted]. 
In addition to target species, tropical tuna fisheries catch non-target
species collectively referred to as bycatch. These species can be
discarded at sea, retained to be sold on local markets or consumed on
board [@amandeBycatchEuropeanPurse2010a]. In the Indian Ocean, 
purse seiners have the obligation to retain bycatch on
board since 2018 (IOTC Resolutions 17/04 and 19/05) with the exception
of species concerned by non-retention measures (e.g., turtles,
cetaceans, rays, most sharks). Even if the ratio of bycatch to target tuna catch
is relatively low for tropical tuna PS fisheries [roughly 5-10\%\;
@kaplanSpatialManagementIndian2014a], the impact on pelagic
populations and ecosystems can be important, specifically for long-lived
species with low reproductive rates [for example, sharks and rays\;
@dulvyExtinctionRiskConservation2014; @pacoureauHalfCenturyGlobal2021].
Efforts to reduce bycatch are mandated for sensitive or protected
species, or species that are essential to the proper functioning of the
marine ecosystem [@ReportExpertMeeting2020]. However, impact studies for
bycatch species are often complicated by a lack of bycatch data recorded
in fisheries logbooks, which typically only include data on target
species.

For this purpose, observers are deployed on board fishing vessels to provide
data on bycatch (specific composition, numbers and size samples) and
discards of tunas. In the case of the French PS fleets in the Indian and
Atlantic Oceans, 10-20% of fishing trips are covered by observers financed by the European Union Data
Collection Framework (DCF), with a complementary observation program
supported by industry [@goujonCollectingDataBoard2017] increasing total observer coverage to
approximately 50% of fishing sets in
the Indian Ocean and nearly 100% of fishing sets in the Atlantic Ocean.
Though these partial data provide essential information on bycatch rates and
species compositions, accurate estimates of *total* PS mortality of specific bycatch species,
including uncertainties, are essential to understanding mortality rates
and causes, and identifying population trends and overfishing. Similar issues of
partial observer coverage are impediments to accurately quantifying the full impact of
fishing on bycatch species in numerous tuna and non-tuna fisheries worldwide. 
In addition, understanding the
extent to which bycatch is predictable based on fishing, spatio-temporal
and environmental covariates is essential to developing effective
spatial management [@ponsTradeoffsBycatchTarget2022]. Therefore, the
objective of this study is to develop robust statistical models for
predicting the catches of bycatch species as a function of various
covariates, including the quantity of target tunas caught, the time and
the location of fishing activities and associated environmental conditions. 
These models will allow us to both
estimate total bycatch mortality for the French Indian Ocean PS fleet
and help us understand the links
between target species, bycatch species and the environment, improving
fishery-based population status indices and enhancing management
capacity for these under-studied species.

One persistent challenge for modeling bycatch of relatively rare species
is the large number of absences observed in the data 
(e.g., in the Indian Ocean, silky sharks, the principal shark species caught by PS, 
are absent from approximately one quarter of fishing sets), 
which typically
prohibits the use of simple statistical models that do not explicitly
account for both bycatch presence-absence (i.e., ones and zeros) and
abundance when present (i.e., number of individuals caught per set given that at least one individual was caught in the set; hereafter referred to simply as "abundance" when there is no risk of confusion). Moreover, presence-absence and abundance may be
partially driven by different biological processes [@stockComparingPredictionsFisheries2020].
Therefore, it seems reasonable to model these two processes separately, combining model results in the end to develop a final prediction of bycatch. This type of modeling approach is known as a $\Delta$ model,
and it has been used successfully for modeling catch per unit effort of
non-target species [@ortizAlternativeErrorDistribution2004] and target
species [@shonoApplicationTweedieDistribution2008]. It has the advantage
over standard statistical distributions (e.g., normal, log-normal and
Poisson), zero-inflated distributions (e.g., the zero-inflated
Poisson distribution) and distributions that permit integrated modelling of presence-absence and abundance data (e.g., Tweedie distribution) in that it allows for greater flexibility and a more pragmatic approach by
separately modeling of each aspect of bycatch
abundance. For example, a random forest model, a machine learning modeling
approach often used for binomial response variables, can be used to
estimate presence-absence of a bycatch species, whereas a general
additive model (GAM), a non-linear, semi-parametric approach to modeling
continuous variables, can be used for abundance when present. In addition to
providing maximum flexibility when estimating each aspect of bycatch,
this approach allows us to examine results from the individual models
separately, as well as in combination.

Below we develop a series of $\Delta$ models for four major bycatch
species (silky shark, *Carcharhinus falciformis*; common dolphinfish,
*Coryphaena hippurus*; rainbow runner, *Elagatis bipinnulata*; rough
triggerfish, *Canthidermis maculata*) of the French tropical tuna purse seine
fishery in the Indian Ocean based on logbook and observer data. First, we
identify optimal modeling approaches and model formulations for
presence-absence and abundance of these bycatch species using a multi-step approach
based on multiple modeling frameworks, multiple distribution families for residuals,
predictor variable selection and cross-validation of results. Next, we combine $\Delta$
model outputs with observations to estimate total annual bycatch of the four species including uncertainties in those predictions. 
Finally, we compare our results to a simpler bycatch-to-landings ratio approach currently extensively
used for bycatch reporting to regional fisheries management organisations.
We end with a discussion of results and their implications for fisheries management.
Code for carrying out all analyses is made freely available
(<https://github.com/Agathedumont/modeling-bycatch-abundance-delta-method>) so that the approach can be applied worldwide in other fisheries.


# Material and methods

## Fishing activity data

The primary data used in this study are catch data for target tunas
from logbooks (i.e., mandatory declarations) and
bycatch species from observer data from the Indian Ocean French tropical tuna purse seine
fishery between `r minyr` and `r maxyr`. The Exploited Tropical Pelagic
Ecosystems Observatory (Ob7) of the French National Research Institute
for Sustainable Development (IRD) collects and manages fishery and
observer data from the French tropical tuna purse seine fleet in the
Atlantic and Indian Oceans. Though the approach we develop could be
applied in the Atlantic and elsewhere, we choose to consider only data
from the Indian Ocean for which \~`r obs_coverage`% of all fishing sets
have observer coverage (~`r obs_coverage_fob`% if only floating object fishing sets are
taken into account). Data on fishing set vessel, time, location, school type and 
catch in tonnes of the
three major target tunas (skipjack tuna, yellowfin tuna and bigeye tuna)
were obtained from captain logbooks data corrected for bias in species
composition based on port sampling using the T3 procedure [@pianetNewSamplingData2000]. Data on
bycatch per species in number of individuals for each fishing set were
obtained from onboard observers as part of two PS observer programs: the
European Union-funded "Data Collection Framework" (DCF; Reg 2017/1004
and 2016/1251) and the “Observateur Commun Unique Permanent” (OCUP) program 
initiated and funded by the PS fishing industry
[@goujonCollectingDataBoard2017]. Each line of the data corresponds to a
fishing set, i.e., a single fishing activity involving encircling a tuna
school with the seine and bringing the fish caught within the seine on
board. The data
extraction initially had `r format(sets_total,big.mark=",")` sets, of which
`r format(obs_sets,big.mark=",")` sets had observer data.

Two fishing modes are commonly used in the Indian Ocean tropical tuna
purse seine fishery [@kaplanSpatialManagementIndian2014a]. 
"Free-swimming school (FSC)" sets correspond to
catch on tuna schools not associated with any object in the water and
detected by crew members during a fishing trip, either visually or via
use of technologies, such as bird radars. FSC sets are generally composed
of monospecific individuals in which bycatch species are rare
[@kaplanSpatialManagementIndian2014a]. "Floating object" (FOB) sets
consist of fishing on tuna schools associated with natural objects at sea
(e.g., logs, palm branches or debris from human activities, such as
marine cargo) or artificial floating objects specifically deployed by PS
vessels to aggregate tunas, referred to as drifting fish aggregating
devices [dFADs\; @daviesPresentFutureUse2014], which today represent the vast majority of floating objects [@maufroyMassiveIncreaseUse2016].

FOB sets represent \>80% of recent PS catch in the Indian Ocean
[@flochStatisticsFrenchPurse2021] and have roughly three
times the bycatch per set of FSC sets, including some emblematic species
susceptible to overfishing, such as silky sharks, that are rarely caught in
FSC sets [@kaplanSpatialManagementIndian2014a]. Therefore, we limited our
analyses to FOB sets. After limiting data to FOB sets, our data set
consisted of `r format(sets_fob,big.mark=",")` sets distributed throughout the 
PS fishing zone in the Indian Ocean (Fig. \@ref(fig:studyarea)), of which
`r format(obs_sets_fob,big.mark=",")` sets have observer
coverage.

(ref:studyarea) Map of the spatial distribution of FOB fishing sets in our dataset from the French purse seine fleet in the Indian Ocean between `r minyr` and `r maxyr`. Black dots indicate sets without observer coverage, whereas red dots are sets with observer coverage.

```{r studyarea,fig.cap="(ref:studyarea)"}
data(World)
tm_shape(World,is.master=FALSE) + tm_polygons() +
  tm_shape(data_for_models |> st_as_sf(coords=c("lon","lat"),crs=4326)) + 
  tm_dots(col="observer",palette=c("black","red")) +
  tm_layout(legend.show = FALSE) +
  tm_graticules()
```

As bycatch data contain well over 100 species or species-groups, many of
which are very rare, we focused our study on four of the more common and
emblematic bycatch species [@ruizBycatchEuropeanAssociated2018]: silky shark (*Carcharhinus falciformis*),
rough triggerfish (*Canthidermis maculata*), rainbow runner 
(*Elagatis bipinnulata*) and common dolphinfish (*Coryphaena hippurus*). Top
predators such as silky shark and common dolphinfish are typically found
as individuals or in small groups in PS sets, whereas rainbow runner
and rough triggerfish are often caught as part of large aggregations. Silky shark
is generally considered to be the PS bycatch species of most concern due
to it being caught in relatively large numbers in FOB sets and due to its life
history traits common to many sharks of high longevity and low
reproductive rates [@dulvyExtinctionRiskConservation2014]. As such, though
models are developed for all four bycatch species, certain results are only
presented in the main text of the article for silky shark, with results for
the other species being presented in the online supplementary materials.

Observer bycatch data separates bycatch observations into three categories: live release, dead release and retained (i.e., landed). Given our objective of estimating mortality rates and a number of indications that sharks released live by purse seine vessels have high post-release mortality [e.g., @hutchinsonPostreleaseSurvivalJuvenile2015; @onandiaNewAssessmentAccidentally2021], for the sake of this paper we decided to sum all three categories into a total "bycatch" mortality observation for each species for sets with observer coverage. Inclusion of live release individuals will have a tendency to overestimate true mortality rates.

## Environmental data {#envdata}

As we wished to understand how bycatch rates vary as a function of 
spatial, temporal and environmental covariates, we first identified a set of environmental variables
that potentially impact bycatch in tropical tuna purse seine fisheries.
Sea surface temperature (SST) and salinity (SSS) and depth integrated net primary production (NPP)
were identified as general environmental variables potentially important for the distribution and abundance of pelagic species [e.g., @mannocciPredictingBycatchHotspots2020a]. Surface mixed layer depth (MLD) was also considered as it can limit the vertical distribution of species,
modifying the accessibility of tuna schools to surface fisheries, among
other effects [@arrizabalagaGlobalHabitatPreferences2015].

Environmental variables were obtained from Copernicus (the Earth observation component of the European Union’s Space programme) at different spatial scales and attributed to fishing observations by associating each point observation with Copernicus data of the containing grid cell and closest timestamp.
Daily sea surface potential temperature and salinity, and surface mixed layer depth were
obtained from the Copernicus - Global Ocean Physics Reanalysis based on the
current available real-time global forecasting CMEMS system, having a
0.083°x0.083° resolution and covering the time period 1993-01-01 to 2019-12-31
(<https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00021>, Accessed 2022-09-01).
Daily primary production was obtained from the Copernicus-PISCES biogeochemical
global hindcast having a 0.25°x 0.25° horizontal resolution with daily
means available from -5500 m to 0 m depth covering the time
period 1993-01-01 to 2020-12-31 (<https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00019>, Accessed 2022-09-01). Net primary production was calculated as the sum of primary production from the sea surface to
200 m depth.

```{r nsets_results}
nsets_total = nrow(data_for_models)

# Table of numbers of sets and individuals for each species
nsetstbl = data_for_models_obs |> group_by() |>
  summarize(total_nsets=nsets_total,obs_nsets=n(),
            across(c(silkyshark,roughtriggerfish,rainbowrunner,commondolphinfish),
                   list(nsets=~sum(.x>0),prev=~sum(.x>0)/n(),nind=~sum(.x),sd=~sd(.x),sdpres=~sd(.x[.x>0])))) |>
  pivot_longer(cols=everything(),names_to=c("species","fn"),names_pattern="(.*)_(.*)",
               values_to="count") |>
  pivot_wider(names_from=fn,values_from=count) |>
  mutate(mn = round(nind/(nsets/prev),2), mn_pres = round(nind / nsets,2),
         CV = round(sd/mn,2)) |>
  mutate(prev=round(prev*100,1),
         species=c(total="Total FOB sets",obs="FOB sets with observers",crit_species)[species]) |>
  rename(` `="species",`No. sets`="nsets",`Prevalence (%)`=prev,`No. individuals`="nind",
         `Mean no./set`=mn,`Mean no./set when present`=mn_pres) |>
  select(-sd,-sdpres)

# For text
nsets = (nsetstbl |> filter(` `=="FOB sets with observers"))$`No. sets`
nsets_silky = (nsetstbl |> filter(` `=="Silky shark"))$`No. sets`
nsets_no_silky = nsets - nsets_silky
perc_no_silky = round(100*nsets_no_silky/nsets)

nsets_str = format(nsets,big.mark = ",")
nsets_no_silky_str = format(nsets_no_silky,big.mark = ",")
```

A conceptual overview of our modeling approach is presented in Fig. \@ref(fig:conceptualoverview). 
In initial exploratory analyses of bycatch data, we noted that zeros
(absences) are prevalent in the data at levels that are not consistent
with standard statistical distributions. For example, `r nsets_no_silky_str`
(`r perc_no_silky`%) of the total `r nsets_str` FOB sets with observer coverage included no
silky shark bycatch (Fig. \@ref(fig:ggplotsilkysharkcap), Table \@ref(tab:nsetstbl)).
As such, we chose to develop $\Delta$ models to estimate total bycatch. The
$\Delta$ method breaks catch down into two separate models, one for
presence-absence and the other for abundance when present
[i.e., the number of individuals of a bycatch species caught in the fishing set given that at least one individual was caught\; @ortizAlternativeErrorDistribution2004]. Total bycatch in a given set is estimated
as the product of predictions from these two sub-models. This methodology has the advantages of allowing for different model formalisms and structures in the two components, thereby permitting greater flexibility than other approaches to dealing with large numbers of zero observations, such as zero-inflated models and integrated likelihood models. 

Given the potential for non-linearity of the relationships between spatial, temporal and environmental predictors and response variables (i.e.,
presence-absence or number of individuals of a bycatch species per set),
we developed models that explicitly permit
non-linearity. When modeling presence-absence of a bycatch species, sets for which any
non-zero number of the species were recorded by observers were assigned
a one, and all other sets were assigned a zero. We compared two overall
modeling frameworks to model presence-absence: (i) general additive
models [GAMs\; @woodGeneralizedAdditiveModels2017] 
with a binomial distribution for the response variable, and
(ii) random forest (RF) models  [@breimanRandomForests2001b]. 
Details of both approaches are given below in Sections \@ref(gammethods) and \@ref(rfmethods).

When modeling abundance when present for a bycatch species, the number of
individuals observed (or a direct function thereof) was used as the response variable and all sets for
which the species was not observed were removed. For abundance, only
GAMs were developed, but several candidate statistical distributions for
the response variable were explored: Poisson, negative binomial,
Tweedie and log-normal.

### Predictors variables

Spatial, temporal, environmental and vessel identifier variables were
included as covariates in models (Table \@ref(tab:tabdescriptionfactors)).
Spatio-temporal factors may have an effect on bycatch as species
abundance and catchability vary on seasonal, inter-annual and regional
scales [@kaplanSpatialManagementIndian2014a]. To take this into account,
models included longitude and latitude, as well as the month and year as
explanatory variables. Month and year were treated as continuous
variables, and month was modeled as a circular variable in GAMs.
Both direct and interactions terms were included in GAMs when
examining the impacts of longitude and latitude, and of year and month
(i.e., in the notation of the `mgcv` R package, both "s()" and "ti()" terms were
included in models).
The effects of longitude and latitude in GAMs were stratified by quarter of the year.
Unfortunately, for random forest, it is not possible to treat month as a
circular variable. Nevertheless, we chose to keep month as a continuous
variable as this allows random forest models to associate (or not) temporally adjacent
months (other than December and January) in an ordered fashion.

In addition to these spatio-temporal variables and the environmental variables 
described in Section \@ref(envdata),
the total catch of target tunas (i.e., all three major tropical tuna
species summed together) in tonnes per fishing set was also included in
our models as it has been extensively used as a predictor of PS bycatch
[@amandeBycatchEuropeanPurse2010a]. Finally, we included the potential
for persistent differences among vessels in terms of bycatch species
composition via the inclusion of a categorical vessel identifier in models as a fixed effect so as to be able to predict bycatch per set for specific vessels.

Models including all the predictor variables listed above will be referred to as "full"
models, whereas models post variable selection
to reduce model complexity and/or decrease problems of model
overfitting will be referred to as "optimal" models (see Section \@ref(modselect) for the variable selection methodology used). Before fitting models, 
cross-correlation analysis among predictors was carried out to understand 
potential for variable redundancy in model formulations and, if need be, remove any redundant
variables (see Results section).

(ref:tabdescriptionfactors) Description of potential predictors of bycatch per FOB fishing set. The "Abbreviation" column gives the short name for each variable that will be used in text, figures and tables. The "95% interval" and "Mean" columns refer to the central 95% of the data and the mean of the data over FOB fishing sets with observer coverage in our dataset.

```{r tabdescriptionfactors,echo=FALSE}
